head_text.subj: TIME LAPSE- NORTHERN PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT

text: Dutch shakes Parcher's shoulder. He jerks violently awake gets a hand on his revolver before he recognizes Dutch.
Jesus. Dutch.
Parcher, it's your watch.
I ain't been asleep two seconds.
An hour. More. I need sleep.
God damnit. Parcher GROANS, sits up.
PALE SHAPES move in inky darkness. RATTLES, PURRING.

head_text.subj: TIME LAPSE- NORTHERN PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT

text: Dutch opens his eyes, sees the campfire blazing unusually high. Callaghan’s blankets are empty. He rolls away from the fire, and sees Parcher’s blankets empty. He’s all alo Dutch sits up fast. He looks around. The camp is complete empty. He grabs his pistol, gets to his feet. The harsh glare of firelight reveals a circle of grass, b obscures the moonlit ocean of movement beyond.

Callaghan. Parcher. Dutch squints into the darkness. He takes a step out towa the grass and stops. Over the CRACKLING of the fire the nighttime sounds seem amplified, SHIFTING in the grass. A moment of uncertainty We see him from a distance, standing vulnerable in a circ of firelight, surrounded by infinite darkness. GURGLING RATTLES slide through darkness. He tightens his grip on his pistol. FOOTSTEPS in the grass behind him. Dutch spins. A FIGURE approaching.
Dutch. I can’t find Parcher. The figure resolves into Callaghan. Relief sweeps over Dutch.
...Why’s the fire so big?
I woke up from the heat of it and Parcher was already gone. Something’s up. Callaghan shakes his head. Dutch rubs the sleep out of hi face. He looks around. It hits him.
He's... using us. The Indians see our fire, attack us. Parcher sees the Indians.  71.
+..Son of a bitch. They stand for a moment, looking out into the darkness. T Callaghan starts kicking wood away from the fire.
Spread it out, we'll let it die down . Dutch kicks from the other side. The fire's quickly lower Dutch and Callaghan left standing over scattered, burning logs. A beat.
Is there more coffee? Callaghan shakes his head, no. The insect-like PURRING that's been rattling off the planes SWELLS.
Do you hear that? Dutch frowns, straining to listen. The PURRING builds and drops, hard to distinguish from the swaying of the grass.

It's almost like... His voice trails off. Dutch listens. A beat. Parcher SCREAMS, off-screen. Dutch and Callaghan's heads snap to the sound. Dutch is the first to move, he grabs a burning piece of w and charges into the grass towards the sound of Parcher's voice, into the darkness. The RATTLING gets louder. On the edge of Dutch's vision, three figures are crouched the ground. Dutch throws his torch. It arcs end-over-end, sailing through the air, and lands the midst of the three. A HISSING SCREAM. The shower of sparks and muted flame reveals- TWO BURROWERS crouched over Parcher. The brief light give a glimpse of the creatures, somewhere between a molting beetle and a drowned child. But only a glimpse. Dutch raises his rifle.  72. The Burrowers, out of the torch's light, nearly invisible slither like melted wax over the soil. CRACK, CRACK, Dutc fires his rifle at the creatures. CRACK, CRACK- THUNK, THUNK, bullets strike the creatures without effect They wiggle into the dirt, and in a matter of seconds, va down into it. Dutch looks at the moonlit grass, collapsing in CIRCULAR INDENTATIONS where the Burrowers dug down. (Just like the indentations they’ve found on the trail.)
What... what... Dutch is on the edge of losing his shit.
My neck. Dutch looks down. Parcher has a half-inch deep, seven-inc long TRENCH carved into his neck.
Callaghan searches through the saddlebags. Dutch is standing, looking out at the plains. The PURRING RATTLE i all around them. Parcher sits by the fire, gingerly touch the wound on his neck.
Do we have bandages?
It ain't bleeding. I can't even feel it. Parcher presses the palm of his hand against the wound, t takes his hand way and looks at it.
Jesus. Now I can't feel my hand. What did that Indian do?
Those weren't Indians. Callaghan pulls a bottle of whiskey and a canteen of wate from the saddlebags, and throws them to Parcher.
Here, clean it out.  73. Parcher ignores the water, takes a drink of whiskey. Callaghan spits, mutters-—
...what right you had to stake us out like pieces of bait.
Listen, I'm the one who's god-damn cut. Dutch even got a look at ‘em.

Those weren't Indians. Dutch crosses to the fire, adds a handful of dead grass. fire FLARES and in the light they can see the grass movin around their camp. RATTLES, HISSES. Some of the grass see to move against the wind. The GURGLES and PURRING comes from all directions.
They're all around us.
I can't feel my face.
I think... they're waiting for us to go back to sleep.
Fat god-damn chance of that.

The campfire blazes, casting a flickering orange light ov the plains. The three sit in a circle with their backs to the fire; each holds a gun and watches the plains. The side of Parcher's face above the wound is starting to droop like a stroke victim's. They don’t look at one another, but stare out at the grass as they talk.
Can't feel my tongue. Or much of my arm. I'm numb but I itch all over. ...I don't want to die like this, not by pieces.  74.
I don't think it'll kill you. That woman we sent back with Dobie, she was still alive.

There's cold comfort. Parcher is still excited, adrenaline giving a shine to hi eyes behind his slightly slackened face. Dutch looks at h bewildered that he could find some strange pleasure in th Dutch considers, then-
What about Dobie? Parcher looks up, sobering slightly.
He could be out there alone with those...
He must be at the fort by now. (a beat, ) «+-You still got that cross?
Yes... Dutch fishes it out of his shirt and tosses it to Parcher Parcher can't catch it with his numb arm, has to fish aro in the dirt. He picks it up and MURMURS a quick prayer, kisses the cross.
Can I get some of that?
..-Amen. Parcher kisses the cross again and tosses it awkwardly to Callaghan. Callaghan lunges, catches. He kisses it and MURMURS a prayer. Parcher feels the moist groove in his n
Here, man. Callaghan tosses the cross and Dutch catches it.
Keep it.  75.
What, you don't believe? Dutch shakes his head.
Then you need it more than I do.
God-damned Indian must have poisoned the knife. Dutch pockets the cross.
They been alone in this country maybe a thousand years. God knows what devilment they could of thought of in that time.
I don't think it was an Indian that cut you.

Looked like men but weren't. Sneaked up and cut a white man's throat in the night. Sounds Indian to me. They fall silent. The RATTLING and PURRS continue out in swaying grass, still strangely SOOTHING. Dutch looks at Parcher’s wound. Parcher beats his fist against the groun
Whole... damn... arms is numb.
Your wound is the same as the Williams’ dead. Parcher looks at him.
Whoever did that is who took Maryanne. Took the Stewarts. We must be close. Can you ride? Parcher nods, struggles awkwardly to his feet.  76.
Shit. Alright let's go. You don't get me on a horse soon, I won't be able to get on at all.

They ride in a line, Dutch at the lead, followed by Parch and Callaghan. All have drawn guns. The BURROWER NOISES continue from the surrounding plains. The sky is enormous, filled with stars. Parcher's lip han limp, his eyes heavily lidded. Dutch rides slowly at the lead, watching the grass.
They climb a rise in the land. Dutch is nodding on his horse, exhausted. Parcher spurs his own horse forward, alongside the lead.
Dutch.
It's almost light.
Maybe. I'm falling apart.
You'll be alright.
...-If I don't make it back, give that cross to Ms. Gertrude Spacks for me. Or give it to Dobie, tell him it's for his mother.
I’1l do it.
I appreciate it.
A fire. Dutch looks over, Parcher swings his head over drunkenly. Callaghan points at a dot of orange light on the horizon.  77.

The three riders approach FAITH, an attractive, 19-year-o Sioux woman sitting alone by a small fire with her rifle. She watches them steadily with dark, exhausted eyes. Parc calls out, his words drunken through his slackened face.
<Friendly. Peaceful.> Faith looks at Parcher. Her eyes darken. She traces a finger on her own neck, mirroring Parcher's wound-
<You are marked. Burrowers.> Parcher looks at her.
What'd she say?
---Told us to set a spell.

head_text.subj: TIME LAPSE- EXT. FAITHS' CAMP- DAWN

text: Faith's face slightly underlit by the dying embers.
<Faithful.>
Her name's Faith. Parcher, Dutch, and Callaghan sit around the dying fire. Parcher translates with an increasingly bleary voice.
<Burrowers killed my family. Last night I shot my husband so he would not have to suffer the feeding.>
She's talking about the Burrowers. Says they killed her family.
Ask her what a Burrower is.
<Burrower. What tribe?> Faith doesn't even look at him.  78.
<They come every third generation. We tried to escape to the East, past the Great River. We were eight .>
<Burrower. What is it?> Faith looks at him. She seems tired and angry.
We fly over empty plains, grasslands extending forever.
<They were here before white people, before humans even. They feed on buffalo.> We overcome a herd of BUFFALO, hundreds of them stampedin

A lone BUFFALO collapses in a heap on the plains. In the moonlight, a Burrower slithers onto the Buffalo's and RETCHES. It's indiscernible as a pale shadow. Eight Burrowers, just vague shapes in the darkness, roll Buffalo into an open pit.
<They bury food, let it rot. The poisoned cannot sleep.>
Dobie's blue eye stares out of the soil. The ground bulge weakly over his wiggling finger.
They use some kind of poison, bury their food alive. Particles of dirt have collected in the moisture on the surface of Dobie's horribly bloodshot eye. A line of tear traces down his cheek  79.
The mess wagon lays untouched in the clearing. FOUR BUZZA peck at Audrey's corpse, shriveled like a mummy. A buzzar tears her CLAVICLE free and flies away with it.
DUTCH'S DERBY blows by, and out into the grass.
<When the blood is thick and the organs are soft, they return and eat. They drink.>
Eight Burrowers, half-concealed by grass, surround and co the barely disinterred buffalo, mouths fastened onto it.
They eat... soft parts.
Parcher's voice smears clumsily through his numb face.
Soft parts? What does that mean? Parcher shakes his head, he doesn't know.
I like my soft parts. Shit.
<You killed the buffalo. So the Burrowers found other food.> Faith talks to the ground-
<We could not escape sleep. They took five of us. A baby without a breast to feed it died yesterday.> Faith looks at Parcher.
<You should die. The sooner you die, the less you will suffer.> Parcher doesn't translate this.  80.
<How kill Burrowers? Stop poison?> Faith shakes her head.
<My father said the Ute had fought them. But the Ute are as wicked as white men, they will not help.>
Ute Indians know how to kill them.
Does she know how to stop the poison? Parcher looks at Dutch, then turns to Faith. He points at the wound on his neck.
<Heal? Make whole?> Faith nods.
<You can die.>
...The Ute might know.
Where do we find Utes?
There’s probably Ute scouts riding the same route we’re on, though they avoid the trails. We can find ‘em a day’s ride North. There’s a trading post, the Watangwa. If we can make it there...
What about the Stewarts?
What about them?
We can’t stop searching so you can go after your cure.  81.
We find the Utes, they lead us to the Burrower Tribe. We kill the Burrowers, you get your girl, go build that cabin on the prairie, play American. Dutch thinks, not sure to trust Parcher.
Is Faith coming with us?
Yeah. That or I'm shooting her. Parcher smiles at her. She knows better than to smile bac

Dutch watches the landscape roll under his horse. Faith walks along beside the three horses. Parcher has lashed h limp left hand to his saddle horn with a cord. He’s grinn excited like a kid on an Easter-egg hunt. Callaghan looks over at Faith, sees that she is beginning limp, as if afflicted with blisters. Dutch looks at Parcher, is a little disturbed by the fier not-quite-grin on his face, twisted by his slack muscles. There's a DARK SPOT on his jaw, like a BED SORE. Parcher turns his grin on Dutch, who looks away.

Trees again dot the plains. The land rises and falls in gentle swells. Stone domes poke through the ground. Dutch watches Parcher up ahead. A SCARLET BRUISE, like a blemish on rotting fruit, marks the back of Parcher's nec There's a sheen of yellow around it, maybe liquid. Faith is now riding behind Callaghan, asleep against his back. Callaghan veers his horse over towards Dutch's. Parcher is a short distance ahead, out of earshot.
You see that bruise on Parcher's neck?  82.
On his face and hands, too.
He's falling apart.
The Ute Indians will fix him.
You believe that? Dutch doesn’t answer. Callaghan slick and
I'm thinking maybe I ain't so eager to risk my hide for that crazy old shitbird's Indian cure.
We’re not risking anything for him.
You still think you’re gonna find your girl? That Maryanne Stewart? What if that’s happening to her? nods towards Parcher. Dutch looks at the sores, purple-yellow.
What's the ruckus back here? Parcher has slowed his horse, swerves over to join them.
Thought I mighta heard my name.
Just talking.
You boys look bushed. We're already in Ute territory. Couple hours shy of the Watangwa. Parcher spits. His voice comes out in a drunken slur.
I didn't sleep a wink last night. Just lay there with my gun, waiting for something to move. (MORE)

PARCHER (cont'd) Whatever them Indians cut me with, it's got my brain racing like a... like I was a young man again. I feel lucky. Makes me wish I could move my god-damn arms. Parcher LAUGHS. It's maudlin in his stroke-victim slur. Dutch and Callaghan exchange a look.
<Your wound is spotted.> Callaghan starts. Nobody realized she was awake. She nods the wound on Parcher's neck. The wound is marked with tin white fungal dots.
<That's how they will find you.> The grin vanishes from Parcher's slackened face.
What was that?
..-Not a thing.
RATTLES, HISSES, the Burrower PURRING. Pale movement in darkness, like white worms in black soil.
The three horses and four riders approach a tall POLE dri into the ground, rags and feathers hanging from the top.

We're here. Dutch and Callaghan stop their horses. The pole seems to mark the dead center of nowhere. Rocky, forested hills ri up around them. The place looks like desolation, like people have died he from ambush, starvation, or both.
What?
The Watangwa. We made it.  84.
Made it? There’s no “here” here. We’re dead center nowhere. They’re completely alone, exposed, lost in the sparse tre
The Utes’1l come. We just gotta wait. Get me off this horse, my ass feels like soggy bread.
<We shouldn’t stop.> Dutch gets off of his horse and looks around. Callaghan climbs off his horse nervously. Faith looks at him.
No... <Don’t stop. It’s getting dark.> Callaghan looks at her, trying to understand. Faith is exhausted, gestures weakly as she speaks.
<They’11 kill us.> Callaghan imitates her speech, trying to communicate.
<They’1l... kill...?>
<They’11 kill us all.> This time he gets it right, no idea what he’s saying-
<They’11 kill us all.>

head_text.subj: TIME LAPSE- WATANGWA TRADING POST CAMP

text: Your watch, man, I need sleep. Dutch blearily opens his eyes. Callaghan is crouching ove him, speaking low enough so only Dutch can hear.
The old man's still awake. Dutch nods, and sits up from his blankets.  85.

head_text.subj: TIME LAPSE- EXT. NORTHERN HILLS CAMP- NIGHT

text: Dutch sits by the campfire with a rifle across his knees, watching the plains. The RATTLING is soft, but it's there Dutch looks absolutely exhausted.

Your eyes open, bud? Parcher is lying on his back by the fire, heavy-lidded ey staring upwards. The BRUISING on Parcher's face is worse, spreading nearly to his left eye. His left hand is nearly black. He's rotting alive.
Dutch. You hear me, Dutch?
I'm awake.
Real good. You stay that way.
I'll tell you if I fall asleep.
Much appreciated. Dutch throws another piece of wood onto the fire.
You think that boy and his squaw are gonna try to leave us?
I'd sure hate to have to shoot somebody for trying to abandon me out here. Dutch stirs the fire. With each SWELL in the BURROWER RATTLE, Dutch's eyelids are tugged downward.
You hear what I'm saying?

No, I'm asleep.  86. Parcher grins with the half of his mouth he can move. The PURRING from out in the grass swells, Dutch's eyes go a little glassy. Dutch yawns. Parcher grins. The Burrower PURRING swells again, tugging at Dutch's consciousness. Dutch lets his l droop downward. A beat. The CLICK of a cocked his pistol. Dutch's eyes snap open- Parcher is turned, watching the grass on the edge of camp behind them. It MOVES against the wind, in time with the Burrower RATTLING. Parcher's revolver weaves drunkenly at the movement. Dutch raises his rifle. The two gun barrels track the grass' movement, slowly acr the circumference of camp. Neither Parcher nor Dutch noti behind them- A PALE FIGURE rising from the earth on the far side of ca between Callaghan and Faith. The RATTLING grows. The grass moving before Dutch and Parcher pauses, then cu back the way it came. Stalks of grass collapse. Background, out of focus- The Burrower stalking Callaghan arrives over him, and draws back a clawed hand. Loose ear falls from its back and PATTERS softly on the ground. Dutch's eyes dart back at the sound. He YELLS and spins, raising the rifle. Callaghan opens his eyes and SCREAMS. CRACK, CRACK, Dutch fires. The second bullet hits the Burrower and it HISSES, retreating into the grass. The grass behind Parcher and Dutch collapses, and a SECON BURROWER emerges, slinking swiftly towards Dutch. Callaghan scrambles to his feet, likewise Faith. BLAM, Parcher fires his pistol limply into the earth, nea throwing the gun from his rotting hand. Dutch turns at th sound and finds- A GAPING MAW. A toothless mouth as big around as a baby's head, strung with mucous and bile, like a hole punched in sheet of melted cheese. The Burrower's head is mottled yellow and brown flesh, th eyes tiny, subterranean pink, too far apart. The flesh is plated, but soft, like a boiled insect.  87. Dutch throws himself backwards, towards the fire, CRACK, CRACK, firing his rifle into the creature. It jerks backwards, HISSING. Callaghan grabs his pistol off the ground. Faith scramble towards the fire. Parcher turns drunkenly towards Callaghan and raises his pistol. Movement in the grass behind Callaghan. Dutch fires, CRACK, CRACK, into the Burrower before him a insinuates itself into the earth and vanishes. BLAM, BLAM, Parcher fires his pistol at the Burrower behi Callaghan. BLAM, on Parcher's third shot, Callaghan YELLS and drops, holding his leg. Faith grabs the dropped pistol. Sudden silence but for Callaghan's PAINED BREATHING and t dwindling PURR of the retreating Burrowers.
Callaghan. Dutch runs to him. He pulls his belt tight around Callaghan's leg, staunching the flow of blood.
Did you see those things? Jesus Christ. Parcher is glassy-eyed excited, gun in hand, barely able prop himself up. He's almost laughing.
You shot me, goddamnit. Dutch struggles to tie off the impromptu tourniquet, his hands slick with blood. Callaghan HISSES in pain.
I saved your life, boy. Callaghan holds his bleeding leg and stares at Parcher.
<Put more wood on the fire.>
Put wood on the fire, she says.  88. Dutch picks up his rifle in one hand and uses the other t toss more wood on the fire. The firelight jumps, but does little to penetrate the forested hills.
<We should go. We should keep moving. They’ll find him by his wound.> She points at Parcher.
<We leave him, he’s already dead. We need to go.> Dutch looks at Faith, shakes his head-
I don’t understand.
<We must go. We keep moving or we die.>
What’s she saying?
Nonsense. The squaw’s hysterical. Dutch shakes his head. He takes Faith’s hands and lifts them. He gestures.
Use hands. Sign.
Oh great Christ. Dutch ignores him. Faith gestures to Callaghan, Dutch, an the horses, then makes a moving gesture, thrusting a hand back out of the trees.
She wants us to go. Callaghan, Parcher, and Faith are all looking at Dutch. H decision is going to determine their course.
What do you think?  89.
No! You’re not gonna listen to that red-skinned bitch! Dutch looks at Parcher, makes his decision.
She knows more than we do. (to Callaghan) Can you ride?
I don't know. If you get me ona horse, yeah, maybe.
Like hell. Parcher dumps the spent cartridges from his gun. He shove fresh round into one the five chambers. Dutch starts towards him. Parcher shuts the breach and raises the pistol. Dutch stops.

We're staying right god-damn here. Dutch looks at him, he’s only six steps away, and Parcher barely able to lift the pistol. He steps forward. Parcher pulls the trigger. CLICK. Dutch lunges forward. Parcher pulls the trigger, CLICK. And again... Dutch yanks the gun out of his hand before the hammer can fall. Parcher flails his arm and YELLS like a toddler ina tantrum. (Like a half-paralyzed, rotting toddler in a tantrum.) He catches his breath, then-
God damn you to hell, Dutch.

The four riders lope along in a line. Faith behind Callag at the lead, nearly holding him in the saddle. Parcher slumped on his horse, hands tied at the wrist to the pomm Dutch brings up the rear, weary. Their horses pick their way slowly through the darkness. Callaghan sweats, grimacing with each bounce of his horse Dutch watches the moonlit landscape, silvery and dim.  90.
You boys better hope to God I die. Nobody answers.
<More blood is coming.> She says it to Callaghan, gesturing to his leg. Blood is dribbling off the heel of his boot. He's near the point o falling unconscious. He pauses, calls out-
...Dutch. We gotta do something about my leg. He reins his horse to a halt. Ahead, Parcher grins throug his stroke-victim face.

Dutch adjusts the flame on a second lantern, the two smal fires together casting an ellipse of weak light. He leaves his rifle by the lanterns, stands, and crosses Callaghan's horse, which Faith holds by the reigns.

Here. Dutch reaches up and helps Callaghan off the horse. Callaghan leans heavily on Dutch's shoulders, grimacing a hissing with pain. He YELLS when his left leg touches ground. His right leg hangs limp, soaked with blood. Parcher watches, almost amused. Then he looks past them, into the darkness. Suddenly, yelled from outside the firelight-

Good Indian! Peaceful! Good Indian! All eyes snap towards the sound. Dutch looks at his rifle. It's ten feet away, by the lanterns; he can't grab it without dropping Callaghan. TWO UTE WARRIORS walk into the circle of lantern light. O is Tall, the other Short. The short one points at himself  91.
Good Indian. (Ute, s.t.) <Are you able to speak?> Nobody responds. Both Ute are armed with RIFLES slung aro their backs. The Shorter Ute has three BEARTRAPS on his b
No English. Dutch looks towards his rifle, then back at the Ute.
Drop me. Get the rifle.
<Ute.>
Praise God, He sent us some Utes. I don't know any Ute words.
Frangais?
<Yes. I speak French.>
<Good. To speak French. We... good Indian. Friends.>
<We look for a missing white family. Burrowers took them.> The Tall Ute leans down and MURMURS something to the Shor one. He nods towards Parcher.
Get your rifle.
Can you stand?
Drop me. The Short Ute addresses Dutch again, pointing at Parcher.  92.
<Dead man. We are to fix. Little fish? We come from south. We hunt. Little fish to hunt with.>
He says they can fix you. Something about a small fish. <I don't understand.> The Tall Ute is moving towards Parcher.

Stay back! Tell him to stay back! The Short Ute shows his palms, trying to calm Parcher. Th Tall Ute keeps advancing. He pulls a bundle of TROPHIES f his belt, hanging on a loop of rawhide. They are trinkets jewelry, snatches of cloth.
<Little fish. We use the sick as Little fish, understand?> He shakes the bundle of trophies.
<From the sick.>
He keeps saying Little Fish.
Jesus Christ amighty. He's talking about bait.

Drop me. The Tall Ute reaches up and grabs the ropes binding Parch wrists to the saddle. Dutch drops Callaghan and dives for his rifle. Callaghan CRIES OUT in pain. Parcher gives a slurred YELL as he's yanked off the horse onto the ground, the Tall Ute holding him. Parcher flails the Tall Ute, knocking the hoop of trophies from his hand The trophies fall to the ground.  93. Dutch gets a hand around his rifle when BLAM, the earth i kicked up two feet from him. Faith SCREAMS. The Short Ute is pointing his rifle at him.
<To take the Little Fish. We fix.> Dutch stays frozen over his rifle. Callaghan half-lies on the ground, holding his bleeding leg.

Shoot this son of a bitch! Pick up your god-damned rifle and shoot this son of a bitch! "Shoo zis sunuvabish" is how the words come out, slurred almost beyond understanding by now. The Short Ute holds h rifle on them as the Tall Ute drags Parcher across camp a past him, into the darkness.
<Little Fish already dead. Little Fish for trap. To kill.>

God damn you, Dutch! Don't let them take me! You killed me, you son of a bitch! Parcher and the Tall Ute are already out of the light of fire and out of sight. The Short Ute, holding the rifle o them, begins to back out of the firelight.
<We are to fix. We are to kill.> The Short Ute backs into darkness and vanishes. Dutch stares into the darkness, the Short Ute could still just beyond the firelight, still pointing the rifle.
Are they gone?
I don't know. A beat. Dutch is the first to move. He crouches down and picks up the loop of trophies.
<We leave. He is already dead. We leave now.>
A dozen trinkets taken from dead settlers, belt buckles, jewelry, crosses. In between each trinket, there hangs a small grayish-white bone, like half of a child's jaw, toothless, non-human.
I hope you’re not thinking of going after him.
They said they could fix him. Or trap... Dutch falls silent, staring at the trinkets in his hand. mouth opens a little, tears shine in his eyes.
Oh god. In Dutch’s hand, hanging from the Ute’s trophy cord, is Maryanne Stewart’s BROOCH. Dutch leans against the horse closes his eyes. Callaghan watches him.
Dutch...? Dutch takes a breath.
She's dead. He stares off into the trees. Several moments- Dutch look on the edge of falling apart; exhausted, heart-broken. Callaghan waits to speak-
Let’s go.
I have to go after Parcher.
Like hell you do. That sunuva bitch was dead ‘fore them Indians even touched him.
It’s not for him. We don’t know how to heal the Burrowers poison. We don’t know to kill them.
I want to go home.  95. We can see that Dutch wants to go home just as badly. He puts the brooch in his pocket. He takes a breath.
They took Maryanne from her home. Home isn’t safe. Callaghan looks at him. Dutch holds his gaze. Callaghan, wearily, nods.

head_text.subj: TIME LAPSE- EXT. NORTHERN HILLS GULCH- NIGHT

text: Dutch pulls Parcher's pistol from his saddle. Callaghan pushes himself painfully into a sitting positio against a saddle lying on the ground. Faith paces nearby, watching the edges of camp. She throws another piece of w on the fire. Dutch crosses to Callaghan and crouches.
You be alright?
No. You hurry back. I think she’ll watch out for me, but... Callaghan gestures towards Faith. Dutch stands, crosses t Faith, and hands her Parcher’s rifle.
Stay? Watch out for him. Dutch points at Callaghan. Tries to pantomime the sentenc Faith takes the rifle, and nods slightly.
Be careful. Dutch takes up his own rifle and nods again. He looks frightened but determined. He takes a breath and walks aw from camp, out of the light of the fire.

The starlight shines somewhere between silver and lead, everything nearly black and white in the dim illumination It could be a daguerreotype. Luminous white-barked birch. Dutch moves through the trees cautiously, rifle in one ha and pistol in the other. He squints into the darkness.  96. WIND moves the small trees, shifting shadows dancing over blowing grass. Burrower RATTLES come and go from seemingl every direction.

Dutch moves deeper into the trees. He seems to be moving towards and away from the Burrower RATTLE at the same tim RUNNING FOOTSTEPS crunch dead leaves. Dutch spins, just a The Short Ute arrives and CLOCKS Dutch across the face wi the butt of his rifle. Dutch drops his rifle and falls to the earth. The Short Ute lands on top of him, hand clampe over his mouth.

<Silence.> CLICK, of a revolver being cocked. The Ute looks down. Dutch's revolver is pointed at his chest. BLAM. The Ute falls backwards, dead before he hits the ground. Dutch scrambles to his feet. The Ute doesn't move. Silenc his smoking gun. He looks around. Nobody but the dead Ute Parcher MOANS from somewhere nearby. It's a low, weak sou nearly a death-rattle. Dutch turns and runs in a crouch towards the sound. He ke his head low, pistol and rifle ready. He jogs through sma trees, CRUNCHING through dead leaves, rises a hill and fi

A bare expanse of rocky earth, surrounded by trees. Dutch passes a pile of SHARPENED POLES, 12-foot birch spe lying piled at the clearing's edge. In the center, Parcher is lying face-up on a slab of rock his arms and legs bound by ropes pegged to the ground. Burrower PURRS and RATTLES surround the clearing. Dutch moves cautiously out towards Parcher.
Jesus, Dutch. Thank God. Dutch leans down over him and unties Parcher's good arm.  97.
They put something in me. Made me drink...

Drink? What was it? Dutch reaches across to untie Parcher's rotten arm. Parch glances past Dutch and GASPS. Dutch follows Parcher's eyes, glancing over his shoulder. Parcher LURCHES upward and GRABS the pistol from Dutch's waist, pointing it at the TALL UTE suddenly behind Dutch. BLAM, Parcher FIRES the gun, inches from Dutch's face. Th muzzle flash SEARS across Dutch's eyes, he falls backward A bullet wound PUNCTURES the belly of the Tall Ute. DUTCH'S POV- Washed-out, overexposed, a RINGING in his ea Dutch stumbles backwards, holding his flash-blinded eyes. His left foot pushes through a pile of dead leaves and SN a BEAR TRAP springs up, biting his ankle. Dutch SCREAMS and falls to the ground. The Tall Ute is half crab-walking, half dragging himself away, bleeding heavily from the gut. Parcher holds the pistol on him blearily, his arm swaying. Dutch is close to shock, his POV bleached nearly white. The Ute, near the edge of the clearing, lets himself collapse, holding his belly. Parcher lets the pistol drop and lies back on the rock. Dutch wedges his fingers beneath the jaws of the bear tra He pulls, straining. The jaws begin to separate... then a fingernail tears and the trap SNAPS shut again.

shit! FROM ABOVE- The Ute lies bleeding near the clearing's edg Parcher lies tethered by three points to a rock. Dutch si struggling to free his leg from the bear trap. SIX INDENTATIONS appear in the rocky soil, churning. SIX BURROWERS emerge into the clearing. They slink like cats, moving on all fours.  98. They cast their heads towards the Ute, and Dutch, then fo in on Parcher and spiral in towards him. Parcher is the first to see them. He GASPS. Parcher weakly lifts the dropped gun and BLAM, fires once before the first two Burrowers are on him. Dutch looks up at the sound, just in time to see the othe four Burrowers FLING themselves onto Parcher. They fasten their gaping maws onto his body like piglets on a sow. Parcher opens his mouth to scream, but the only sound tha comes out is the dying WHEEZE of a broken bellows. The Burrowers arch their backs and suck, SLURPING the rotten organs from Parcher's body. A Burrower pulls its pale head away from the buffet, its dripping with blood and gore, as if fresh from a pie-eati contest. It swings its head towards Dutch. Dutch, still tethered by the bear trap, looks at the creature. It HISSES with a blood-and-mucous strung mouth. Dutch crabwalks backwards, away from the Burrower, pullin the trap's tethering chain nearly taught before he FREEZE He looks down at his left hand, a SECOND BEAR TRAP waits beneath a thin covering of leaves. The Burrower starts slinking towards him. The thick yello nails on it's three-fingered hands drip white venom. Dutch looks from the bear trap blocking his path to the approaching creature. It’s ten feet away. It tenses to pounce, HISSING, then FLINGS itself at Dutch. Dutch YELLS, and catches the Burrower's hand, the drippin talons inches from his neck. He twists, pushing the creat onto the SECOND BEAR TRAP. The trap SNAPS, CRUNCHING into the Burrower's side. The Burrower ARCHES and SCREACHES in pain. Dutch rolls away, and from the ground grabs a STICK, arm- length, about two inches around. He wedges it into the ja of the trap holding his ankle, and pries it apart. The trapped Burrower, arm's length from Dutch, LUNGES at swiping. Dutch YANKS his leg free and rolls away, the venomous claw missing him by inches.
<No!>

Dutch looks over. Another BURROWER is slinking towards th gut-shot Ute, talons dripping. The Ute cries out. Dutch LURCHES to his feet, his wounded ankle nearly givin out, and limps to intercept the creature before it reache the Ute. One of the Burrowers still feeding on Parcher suddenly li its head and HISSES. It stumbles back from Parcher, drunkenly, and then collapses to the ground. The other three Burrowers raise their bloody maws from Parcher's drained corpse and look over. The unconscious Burrower lies on the ground, sucking small, shallow breat like an asthmatic child. The Burrower bearing down on the wounded Ute weaves drunkenly, but is only paces away. PANTING with pain, Dut grabs a SHARPENED POLE from the pile on the ground. The Burrower raises back a claw, ready to swipe at the Ut Dutch lunges, PLUNGING the birch pole through the Burrowe torso and into the ground below. The creature SCREECHES. The bear-trap Burrower's eyes are closed, it pushes weakl against the ground. The three Burrowers over Parcher stumble away, drunkenly. The Burrower speared to the ground wearily lolls its head

+-.-You poisoned them. The Ute, breathing through clenched teeth, almost grins. One-by-one, the Burrowers collapse blearily to the ground unconscious. Barely standing, Dutch watches them fall. All six creatures lie unconscious, smeared with Parcher's dark blood, breathing shallowly. Dutch tries to catch his breath. Parcher's body is an empty husk, pale white and mummified His chest and belly collapsed like a sunken soufflé.

Heavenly god. The gut-shot Ute is weakly trying to CALL OUT. Standing over an unconscious Burrower, Dutch gets our fir real clear look at the creatures:  100. Humanoid. Three thick fingers on each hand ending in thic black, curled nails. A half-dozen small, vestigial, beetl looking TALONS, like Alaskan crab legs, line its torso beneath the arms. It has tiny, puckered eyes. Mucous-strung mouths as big around as softballs. Completely hairless. A soft exoskeleton, like a molting insect's, over mottled, rotte looking flesh, a stark contrast against the crimson stain their cheeks and chins. Gooey strings of Parcher's blood blow in and out of the things' mouths in time with their RASPING BREATH. The Tall Ute CALLS OUT to Dutch, barely more than a direc MOAN. Dutch looks over. The Tall Ute's tunic is nearly black with blood in the moonlight. The Ute points across the clearing. Dutch's gaze follows the Ute's hand to the pile of BIRCH SPEARS, the sharpened poles at the clearing's edge. Dutch picks one up. The Tall Ute nods, and points at the Burrower Dutch speared, pinning to the ground. Then he points at the other unconscious creatures, pantomiming thrusting spears into them. Dutch limps over to the nearest Burrower, holds the spear over it, and looks at the Ute. The Ute nods desperately. Dutch kicks the Burrower onto its back, raises the spear, PLUNGES it downward into the thing's chest. The Ute pumps his fist, pantomiming driving the stake dow deeper. Dutch twists the spear and pushes it through the Burrower, down several feet into the ground. The Burrower twists with the pressure and BILE dribbles f its mouth. The Ute looks towards the East, where the first gray ligh dawn is appearing. He turns back to Dutch and points at t other Burrowers. Dutch nods, limps over and grabs two more spears. He kicks the second Burrower onto its back and drives the stake through its chest and into the ground. He drives a stake into the third Burrower. The Ute nods, relieved, and collapses onto his back, PANT Dutch impales the fourth Burrower. The fifth, and the six  101. Dutch stands, the Burrowers are STILL BREATHING. Blood an mucous shakes on their lips with every exhale.
It didn't work. (French, s.t.) <It didn't work> The Ute doesn't look at him.

<They're still alive.> The Ute doesn't respond. Dutch is exhausted and all fucked up, looks like he's about to cry. He walks over to Parcher. Parcher's corpse looks frail as a baby bird. Dutch crouches down and grabs Parcher's corpse from under the arms. He lifts him, and starts to drag him away. He pulls him back six or seven feet before Parcher's boot catches on a rock. Dutch pulls and Parcher's withered left arm TEARS OFF. Dutch falls onto his ass with the mummified limb in his hand. He YELLS and drops it, scrambles backwards, and comes to a rest sitting on the ground. Dutch sits there. He stares at the ground. He looks at the gut-shot Ute lying on the ground. Dutch looks back at the ground and sits. SUNLIGHT hits him. Dutch looks up. The first rays of dawn cresting the horizon. The ASTHMATIC WHEEZING quickens, becomes more urgent. The Burrowers are stirring, limbs moving over the ground. The sun climbs a little higher over the horizon. Light is now falling directly on the six creatures. They WHEEZE and HISS, there is a faint SIZZLING. One Burrower opens its maw and lets loose a high-pitched soun like a DOG WHISTLE. It raises its arms to the spear pinni it to the ground. The others come fully awake, HISSING and SCREAMING. Dutch watches. The Burrowers' skin pulls tight in the sunlight, STEAM rises off of it.  102. A Burrower digs at the ground, uselessly scratching at th earth. TINY BLISTERS appear on their yellowish flesh. A Burrower, SCREAMING, pulls at the stake pinning it to t ground, actually lifting itself off the earth. The gut-shot Ute watches with fierce satisfaction. Burrower skin SIZZLES and CRACKS in the sunlight. BILE bubbles up from their mouths. They STEAM and SCREAM, fles falls from their bodies in blistering scraps. The Burrowe writhe on the ground, their flesh burning away. Huge BLISTERS rise and break. Dutch watches as they SCREAM and fall to pieces. By the time it's done, the Burrowers’ corpses look like B CHILDREN staked to the earth. Dutch, bathed in sunlight, sitting on the ground between Parcher's corpse and Parcher's arm, wipes the tears from eyes with bloody hands.

Callaghan is sitting and Faith pacing where we left them. Dutch, holding the Ute's arm around his shoulder, stumble into camp. The Ute's feet barely drag on the ground, his whole torso dark with blood. He's pale, but conscious.

They have the Ute laid out on blankets, taking shallow breaths. Faith is gently tying strips of blanket around t still-seeping wound in his stomach. Callaghan and Dutch sit nearby. Dutch drinks coffee.
It was sunlight. Burned them alive. The Ute poisoned them. Put something in Parcher that would make the Burrowers sleep.
Parcher's dead? (Dutch nods.) I'll miss him.  103. It's not a convincing performance. A beat, then-
I don't know what the poison was. Callaghan looks at the gut-shot Ute.
Can he talk?
I don't think so. ...If he dies we won't find the poison.
Shit. Nothing's easy.
I can make it to Fort Bismark and back with a doctor in two days.
You think he can live that long?
I don't know. What about you?

-..Get to it. The longer you wait the deader we get. And you better stay dead South. You miss that fort by a few miles, you'll be lost for days. Dutch nods with heavy eyes. He wants nothing but sleep.
And if you gotta sleep, sleep in the day, you hear me?

I won’t sleep. Faith, her hands red with the Ute's blood, watches Dutch Callaghan. Callaghan reaches out a hand, Dutch takes it a they shake. Faith cradles the wounded Ute’s head in her lap. He blear tries to speak, but can’t. Faith is close to tears. The Ute weakly points at Callaghan and Dutch, then covers ears with his hands. Tears roll down his face. Faith cradles his head in her lap.  104.
The rising sun finds Dobie's blue eye, slightly clouded o staring up at the deep blue sky.

location: NORTHERN PLAINS TO SOUTHERN PLAINS- VARIOUS / MONTAG

text: POUNDING HOOVES. From morning to noon to night, Dutch pus his horse hard across the sparse plains, Clay’s horse galloping on a rope tied behind. He switches horses to ke up his speed, eyes raccooned with exhaustion.

Dutch rides, exhausted, world tilting carnival around him Burrower RATTLES swell out of the grass around him. The s GOLD CRUCIFIX, marked with WHITE GROWTHS, bounces inside Dutch’s breast pocket. The grasslands are watching him.

A red sun crests the horizon. ON THE GROUND- Dobie’s eye stares out over the plains. DOBIE’S POV- through the grass, Dobie sees a horse and ri approaching. UNDERGROUND- Dobie’s finger wiggles furiously. The rider is crossing Dobie’s sight diagonally. He gets close enough that we can see that it’s Dutch. We see hope Dobie’s unmoving eye. Underground, his finger wiggles desperately. ON DUTCH- He reins his horse to a stop forty feet from Do looking down at the grass. He grins a little bit and we s what got his attention-- Dutch’s HAT, suspended in the gr He swings down, grabs the hat, and jams it onto his head. ON THE GROUND- Dobie watches Dutch climb back on his hors and ride away.
Dutch stands, waving his arms at a MILITARY TRAIN, a doze Bluecoat soldiers and a mess wagon marching Northward. TW RIDERS break away from the train and head towards him.  105.
CLOSE UP on Dutch's face, exhausted but at least cleaned eating. He watches the OFFSCREEN SOLDIERS talk-
I can't rightly say, sir. He says Will Parcher was killed, and another man named Clay.
Does he know the tribe that attacked him?
No, sir. He's a foreigner, sir. Might be simple.

Dutch sits on a wagon, his left ankle thickly bandaged. H cleaned up, in fresh clothes. A black DRIVER and a DOCTOR sits in the wagon behind them. Six BLUECOATS ride alongsi along with an OGLALA SCOUT. Dutch holds a cane across his lap and watches the prairie ahead of them, anxious to return to his friends-

head_text.subj: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS / MILITARY CAMP- DUSK

text: Faith and the Tall Ute hang dead from an impromptu GALLOW The blood from his stomach wound tracing his legs show th the Tall Ute was still alive when they strung him up. Dozens of BLUECOATS mill around, setting up camp. Standing by the wagon, leaning on his cane, Dutch stares slack-jawed at Faith and the Tall Ute's corpses. His eyes shine with tears. Campfires burn all around him, throughout the trees, a pleasant glow in the quickly fading light.
Parcher's German! Hey, Parcher's German! Dutch turns, Henry Victor walks quickly and warmly toward him, rubbing his hands together with satisfaction.  106.
My god, man. They told me you were here. I'm afraid you were too late for Will Parcher.
I know.

What the hell’d them Indians do? We buried him proper, though. Man was wiser'n I gave him credit. Took four days and no small pain to get them Sioux to tell us what Parcher guessed right off. We've got scouts routing out the Ute to the North as we speak. Were able to clear just about every last one of them from this land. Reg'lar Indians: they could whoop to beat the band but can't fight for shit.
Where's Callaghan?
Who, now?
He was your cook. He was with...
Walnut! He would have owed me his life if he had survived.
What?
Amputated his leg and he up and died on us. Man was delirious, halucinating, never really woke. Tears creep down Dutch's cheeks. Henry Victor's talking t himself, barely notices Dutch is there.

‘Course we never did find them Stewarts. Doubt we ever will, were probably dead before we even started looking. I guess all we can really do is make sure it never happens again.  107. Dutch looks at the ground, crying.
Dutch rides Parcher's horse away from a dozen BLUECOAT SOLDIERS riding South.

We see the settlement from out in the plains, alone ina world of grass. The houses are still unoccupied. We tilt down and reveal six SUNKEN PATCHES in the ground. They’re graves, recently robbed. If we look closely, we c see scraps of bone and withered skin in the grass. A piec of lace from one of the Stewart children’s nightgowns. They were buried less than a 1/4 mile from their homes.
Dutch rides towards the large Victorian home. He eyes the approaching home with trepidation.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE SPACKS HOUSE PORCH- DAY

text: Gertrude, wiping her hands on her apron, opens the door a finds Dutch standing with his hat in hand. Dutch inhales begin speaking...

Dutch perches uncomfortably on a wing-back chair as Gertr WEEPS softly, sitting on the sofa opposite. This has been going on for some time. Dutch holds his hat his knees, moving his hands along the brim. The GOLD CRUCIFIX dangles by its chain from Gertrude's ha Gertrude gets control, wipes at her face with a kerchief.
Have you had lunch, Mr. Leijderova?
Dutch carries a picnic basket, walking next to Gertrude, carries a blanket. They walk towards the box elder tree where the earlier picnic took place.  108.
Dobie's still alive.
I think so, too.
It's not a thinking matter. A mother would know. My son will come back to me. The GOLD CRUCIFIX is looped around Gertrude's neck.
Do you like pineapple?
I don't know.
I think you will. Parcher loved pineapple. She pauses.

I’m sorry about Maryanne. (Dutch nods) Her poor family... I don't want to feel guilty. I think our duty is to live as well as we can. It gives reason to the sacrifices that men like Parcher and you made. A lot of Americans died so we could make a life here. It would be a sin if we didn't. They arrive in the shade of the Box Elder. Gertrude finge the gold cross. It’s still spotted with tiny WHITE GROWTH

The grass moves in amber waves across the slowly sloping land. The cloudless sky casts clear, stark, starlight dow onto the plains. Dobie is pulled from the earth by a doze hungry hands. He’s still alive, still awake when the feed begins.
